reviewText: It feels like Magnifico was never completed. For one, the interface makes it feel as though multiplayer was definitely a plan. There is a blank option box under Singleplayer" and if they had never planned MP
date: why even make you choose singleplayer when it is the only option? I've played three full games and thus far the AI has not once chosen to attack one of my castles. They could have a "Perfect City" (castle with 5 shields) with 15 soldiers
recommended: 3 tanks and 3 planes and not attack my unshielded castle on a tile that generates revenue + soldiers. They'll leave it alone even as I'm attacking them

reviewText:
Short version: 41%Magnifico tried to reinvent Risk with the addition of some twists, but in the end it failed by turning a strategy game into something where skill has absolutely no place next to pure luck.

Long version:I don’t like to form opinions on board games after such a short time of game play, but going through four of the five difficulty levels and all four maps of Magnifico, I have to say, playing one or two games really exhaust everything this board game offers.

The basic premise is a variation of Risk and Catan: 3-4 players fight over a map divided into several territories, gathering army and fortifying home cities along the way. On top of the usual infantry, the players can use tanks that do massive damage, and planes that can bypass fortification defences. All three unit types can be upgraded with the use of cards that are acquired on pre-turn auctions.

In theory, it all sounds great, but in practise this is not a strategy game but a game of chance. Everything is random from territory values to battles: infantry can just fall down and die from nothing, and a malfunctioning tank can instantly wipe out an army regardless of its size.
The cards are chosen randomly, and being lucky enough to have a winning bid on, for example the one that can sacrifice an infantry to reduce city defences to nothing, can pretty much win the game by itself.

Maybe if there would be multiplayer, it could salvage the game, because the computer either never attacks and gathers victory points behind safe walls, or gangs up on the player and steamrolls them. It’s just not fun to play Magnifico, because it is either boring or frustrating.

reviewText:
At $5, this is a steal, and one the company website, you can get the real board game for $14.99.

Magnifico is a clever mixture of artistic and tactical warfare. It's roots are in the Axis and Allies mold, but it plays dramatically different, with the inclusion of cards that make for asymmetrical opponents of varying qualities.

It's an elegant translation of the original board game, and a worthy addition to your library. One can only hope other games, like Dust, will be made into digital format(s) as well.

reviewText:
Only played a single game and enjoyed it - to a point.
It is very risk like in places - but the army building is different.
The card auctions are strange and you have to decide how much to gamble.  If you win the auction, you will get to choose on of the cards.  But, the twist is, bid too much and the 2nd person gets their choice for a fraction of the cost - or drops out completely.
The AI seems to focus on defence - which is ok - but as you get closer to the victory point - doesn't try to use the poweful stacks it has built.
Would be good with a multi-playerr or hot-seat option.
Price is excellent - but this could be a try before you buy and an occasional game.
Overall - i like it and when i get 4 hrs clocked - will feel i've got value for money

Update : The AI level is controlled by picking different characters to play against.  There is a list, and it shows 3\4 by default who seem to be unrated.  Scrolling down shows the higher rated characters.  Only realised this on second game.

reviewText:
I played this a few times, and I can tell you right now, that's all it takes to get bored of this game. There are higher difficulties, but there is still only 3 types of units available to you. After you've played this games limited number of maps, and suffered through about an hour of repetitive gameplay, you WILL start to wonder why you bought this game. Good if you're looking for a simple turn based Risk-like, but not if you were hoping for something more.

On the bright side, it's only $5 dollars, but then again, I got it as part of a humble bundle for much less than that. Only get it if it is part of a bundle.

Moral of the story: Only get on sale/in a bundle.

reviewText:
Overall 6/10

Fully worth the two bucks I've paid for it. It's the electronic version of the same boardgame (think of Risk, with simplified rules and bidding on Da Vinci's inventions gives you an edge).

PROS
+ Good tutorial, you are up and running in 5 minutes.
+ Some mild strategic thinking is required here and there.
+ Solid replayability (different maps, multiplayer).
+ A game can take anywhere between 15 to 30 minutes.

CONS
-  The AI is meh.
-  Lacks any sort of depth.

reviewText: NO MULTIPLAYER! NOT EVEN HOTSEAT! (I guess they were afraid that a digital version would cannibalize sales of the obscure, unpopular board game this is based on?) So every turn the leader of the Ninja Turtles dreams up new military upgrades, and everyone bids for the chance to get them. (Each player makes a secret bid and highest wins. No exciting bidding wars to distract from the drab gameplay here!) Combat uses some kind of weird dice system. You'd expect the tutorial to explain basic details like the dice odds, but no, it's too terrible. The tutorial seems to generally be pretty terrible, telling you what you CAN do without any basic instruction about the strategy behind what you SHOULD do. After I gave up on the tutorial and read the rules, I learned those are bad too - it's just a wall of text without any diagrams (I guess the printing costs were too high? /s) and some of the wording is ambiguous (they make it sound like castles' defence rating increases based on how many tanks are attacking it, but they mean that each tank rolls against the castle separately). The music sounds like really awful stereotypical renaissance fair stuff. Turn it off ASAP and save your sanity.

reviewText: Not the best tabletop game turned video game out there, but still pretty enjoyable.  The available pool of inventions will change each game, and with it, your strategy, but ultimately this game does follow a predictable recipe of race to expand, bunker along a line, then spend to become Magnifico and win.  The various maps do little to prevent this stagnation, although Europe (with its many coastlines) prevents bunkering to some extent.  I'll still go back and play it periodically, but probably quickly remember why I stopped the last time.

reviewText:
This game is a fun boardgame-like game, that actually plays a lot like Risk/War. The problem of the game is the fact that it only has singleplayer mode, it could be a lot of fun playing multiplayers, especially by the fact that this game could use a lot more strategy this way (like pact with your friends and etc.). The game is actually pretty simple, but plays really well, and the projects that you can buy are a nice way to make the game funnier. Especially if you militarize yourself so much that it is hard for the others to defend against you.

Also, this game only has one win condition, points, and it can be easy to achieve these points if you know well what you are doing. The game can be challenging if you're playing with the harder bots, but, if not, it can actually be pretty straightforward and easy. All you have to do is understand how to get those points and win. The game actually should have other win conditions, like conquering, or things like that.

The fact that the game does not have multiplayer is a big turn-off, but you still can have some fun with it. I actually liked to play it for the sole purpose of getting the trading cards, and I don't think I'll come back to it again, but you can buy it for a cheap price, or even a bundle, and have some time of fun with it.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Imagine a world where Leonardo da Vinci's inventions took precidence over his artwork, ushering in an age of steampunk warfare. That's Magnifico in a nutshell. A niftly little strategy game where you conquer territory, use da Vinci's genius to make your troops more powerful, and then throw these troops at each other to grab more territory and earn victory points.\nMy primary gripe with the game is that there are no game modes. Every game end when 30, 40, or 50 points are earned through strength and number of castles, empire size, times you were the top bidder on his projects (the Magnifico) and the number of his projects you were able to purchace (double for Works of Art, a nice addition). You can't toggle the options, you can't go for a domination victory, or an economic voctiry, or a culture victory. It's all Victory Points, all the time.\nFortunately the game board is randomized each time, making the game very replayable. I'd say it's best as one of those games you boot up when you need to kill some time while your laundry is running. Short, easy to dive in to, and it's just a fun concept in general.

reviewText:
Make no mistake, this is a board game for PC. It feels like Risk with a twist, but I find Magnifico a lot more appealing since I don't particularly like Risk.

It has a good tutorial and the rules are always one click away. There are several strategies you can deploy to win the game, but you will always have to use all available mechanics. You need money to get stuff and troops to defend your territories, and technology to gain extra points and upgrade your economy.

Scoring is according to the more" you have. More lands
recommended: more upgraded castles and more tech cards. On your turn you may move troops
voteText: attack enemies
votesHelpful: and activate upgrades. The actions are limited by number of uses and the amount of gold available. Controlled lands supply fixed troops and/or gold every turn. The map is generated randomly at the beginning of the game. A land may either produce 30 gold and 0 troops
votesTotal: or 10 gold and 2 troops every turn
votesFunny:
for example. Siege weapons ("tanks" and "planes") allow you to counter tech cards and fortifications.

It is a simple game to pick up but still manages to deliver a bit of a challenge and get you engaged. I actually find it very relaxing.

The only downside

reviewText:
Quite an interesting game - kinda like Risk but a lot more varied and balanced. Three major improvements over Risk:A massive army won't win you the game. Your infantry spawns in specific places, and trying to get them to your front lines takes time. Also, you can't attack with more than 6 infantry anyway (though you can add up to 6 tanks/planes to that army if you can afford it, for a maximum of 12 attacking units).
Upgrades! Each turn Leonardo Da Vinci offers a certain number of upgrades to the players, and the highest bid gets first pick. This can make your units more powerful, give you extra VPs per turn, and so on.
Victory points are cumulative. If, for example, you have a perfect city, it doesn't give you 1 VP. It gives you 1 VP per turn that you own it. This means that the game doesn't go on forever!{/olist}

There are two negatives to the game, however.
Firstly, the rules aren't as clear as they could be. For example, I don't know how to make a perfect city - it was never explained in the tutorial and a quick skim through the help docs didn't give me an explanation. I'm sure it's in there somewhere, but it should have been clearer.
Secondly, there's no multiplayer at the moment! This really sucks, as I'm sure this game would be so much better with multiplayer, even local hotseat. There's so much wasted potential just by not including multiplayer, and it's a real shame.

In summary: If you like area control games like Risk, but wish it was a bit more varied and interesting, give this game a look. If no multiplayer is a dealbreaker for you, look elsewhere.

reviewText:
I've got a decent playtime out of it. I've honestly enjoyed this game and I was probably one of the first people to pick it up when it was released on Steam and didn't expect so many negative reviews for this game.

The gameplay in my opinion are fantastic, you make a bid every round and if you win, you get first pick to Da Vinci's various war machines and get to go first. There are multiple ways to achieve victory points, such as having the most provinces, or building up castles. Around four maps and three settings the amount of victory types with multiple AI types to choose from. Graphics are pleasing and the gameplay is calm. This game was very useful for nights I didn't feel like sleeping and just skirmished with the AI.

In my opinion, Magnifico is a great game, and its well polished and well done for the price.

reviewText:
Imagine if royalty took Leonardo Da Vinci's inventions seriously and built them for battle: that is what you get in this game. It took a while for me to get used to the gameflow, but I'm finding myself to be really enjoying it.

I got this as part of a humble bundle and I was pleasantly surprised. The interface is pleasant and relatively easy to use.

I do get the gripe about the lack of multiplayer. I thought I had simply received the cheap" version because I bought it through the humble bundle. It would be great if they release an update with multiplayer.

I don't know what other players are saying about the AI: you have to play the harder AIs to be attacked..."
